cschildren.title: Ancestors of specific groups of people

children.title: babies
children.comment: The gift of young children from God is usually seen as a blessing. The term is also used figuratively of those who are young or immature in the faith.

cschildren.title: Babies as a blessing from God
Examples of biblical characters as babies
OT laws concerned with the birth of babies
A mother's love for her baby

children.title: Jesus Christ's own birth and babyhood

cschildren.title: Babyhood used as a spiritual image

children.title: betrothal
children.comment: The period of engagement preceding marriage; betrothal was a binding contract established between two families and sealed by the exchange of gifts. During this period the couple did not live together; sexual relations with each other at this stage was regarded as equivalent to adultery. Betrothal describes the relationship between God and his people and between Jesus Christ and the church.

cschildren.title: Betrothal and the choice of a spouse

children.title: Wives were often chosen by parents for their sons

primaryrefs.comment: It was usual practice for the groom's parents to choose his wife and arrange the wedding.

children.title: Suitable husbands were sought by parents for their daughters

primaryrefs.comment: Naomi, in the role of parent, assumes responsibility to find a husband for Ruth.
Sometimes the man chose a prospective bride and his parents negotiated the marriage.

seealsos.comment: Esau chose a bride against his parents' wishes.

secondaryrefs.comment: A betrothed soldier was exempted from military service until after his marriage

cschildren.title: An exchange of gifts accompanyed betrothal

primaryrefs.comment: This gift, which was given by the groom to the bride's family as compensation, sealed the marriage contract.
The dowry was a gift from the bride's father to the bride and/or groom.
Though there were no sexual relations within the betrothal period, the commitment was regarded almost as seriously as marriage and infidelity of a betrothed partner was treated as adultery.

seealsos.comment: The men betrothed to Lot's daughters are described as his ``sons-in-law''
Mary's pregnancy during betrothal left her open to the charge and consequences of unfaithfulness.

cschildren.title: Betrothal portrays the relationship between God and his people

children.title: birth
children.comment: The beginning or origin of life, in which a living creature comes into the world. Scripture draws a distinction between physical and spiritual birth, insisting that a person must be not only physically but also spiritually born in order to have life to the full.

children.title: Human beings are sinful from the moment of birth

cschildren.title: The agents of the new birth: word and Spirit
The fruit of the new birth: holiness and love
Spiritual birth and the nation of Israel

seealsos.comment: Moses implies that God himself gave birth to the people.

cschildren.title: Birth seen as entry into a condition or status

children.title: Physical or mental disability from birth
birthright
children.comment: The right of the firstborn son in ancient Israel to inherit his father's estate. Where the property was divided, the firstborn received a double share.

cschildren.title: Birthright was recognised amongst the patriarchs

children.title: It was guaranteed under the law

seealsos.comment: some ignored this law

children.title: Daughters and others could inherit if there were no sons
Only sons of a lawful marriage qualified
Succession was normally to the firstborn

seealsos.comment: favouritism could intrude here also

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ is the firstborn over all creation; by the grace of God Christians share in his inheritance.

children.title: boys
children.comment: As those who would continue the family line boys were seen as a great blessing from God. Circumcised on the eighth day, as they grew towards maturity they were to be taught by their fathers. In the story of God's people, Israelite boys are seen serving God, being ministered to by men of God and suffering at the hands of ungodly kings.

cschildren.title: Boys in general are seen as a blessing from God
Particular boys who are seen as a special gift from God

children.title: The boy Isaac, a gift to Abraham and Sarah
The boy Samson, a gift to Manoah and his wife
The boy Samuel, a gift to Elkanah and Hannah
The boy John, a gift to Zechariah and Elizabeth
The boy Jesus, a gift to Mary and Joseph

cschildren.title: Boys were circumcised on the eighth day
Boys were taught by their fathers

primaryrefs.comment: While examples of fatherly instruction in Scripture are confined to wisdom literature and liturgical material, other sources indicate that the education provided was more wide-ranging, and would include the teaching of a trade.

children.title: The boy Samuel served God in the temple
The boy David served God by killing Goliath
The boy King Joash served God
The boy King Josiah served God
The boy Jesus had a conscious relationship with God

cschildren.title: Boys who are ministered to by men of God

children.title: Through Elijah, God restored the life of a widow's son
Through Elisha, God restored the life of a Shunammite's son
Jesus Christ healed a demon-possessed boy

cschildren.title: Both Herod and Pharaoh ordered that Israelite boys be killed

children.title: bride
children.comment: A woman who is about to be married or who has just got married. In the NT the church is described as the bride of Christ.

cschildren.title: Jewels and ornaments worn by a bride at her wedding
Joy and happiness associated with a bride
The bride as the object of the bridegroom's love and affection
The bridegroom as the object of the bride's love and affection
Exemptions for a newly married bride

primaryrefs.comment: A newly married bride would normally be excused from certain civic and religious duties.
A bridegroom was required to pay a bride-price to the father of his bride.

cschildren.title: Proof of a bride's virginity was required in certain circumstances
The church depicted as the bride of Christ

children.title: bridegroom
children.comment: A man who is to be married or who has just got married. In the NT Jesus Christ is portrayed as a bridegroom and the church as his bride.

cschildren.title: The bridegroom and the wedding ceremony

children.title: The bridegroom took part in the procession to the bride's home
The bridegroom had a group of companions
The bridegroom had a special friend as an attendant

seealsos.comment: The ``master of the banquet'' was probably the friend who attended the bridegroom.

children.title: The bridegroom was sometimes responsible for giving the wedding banquet
The bridegroom led his bride to a specially prepared bridal chamber

cschildren.title: Bridegrooms were associated with happiness and rejoicing
Bridegrooms were excused from military service and certain other duties
Jesus Christ is portrayed as a bridegroom

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ refers to himself as the bridegroom.

cschildren.title: The future coming of Jesus Christ compared to the sudden arrival of the bridegroom

children.title: brothers
children.comment: The son of one's parents, or of either mother or father. God's people may be referred to collectively as brothers, all being children of one heavenly Father.

children.title: Participation in arrangement of marriages for sisters
Younger brothers taking news of older brothers to their father

cschildren.title: The priority of the eldest brother
Examples of younger brothers superseding their elder brothers
Examples of brothers failing to live up to expectations of them

children.title: To members of the same tribe
To descendants of a common ancestor

cschildren.title: Love for God must exceed love for brothers
Jesus Christ calls his disciples his ``brothers''
The fraternal relationship among God's people

children.title: Believers urged to love each other
The church referred to as ``the brothers''

cschildren.title: A certificate of divorce was required under Mosaic law

primaryrefs.comment: The certificate provided a divorced wife with some legal protection and permitted her to remarry.

seealsos.comment: These words may have been adapted from a divorce bill

cschildren.title: God gave his unfaithful people a certificate of divorce

seealsos.comment: Unlike Israel, Judah had been given no certificate of divorce. The exile is thus portrayed as only a temporary separation.

children.title: childbirth
children.comment: Seen by Scripture as a token of God's favour, and used figuratively to picture a number of central biblical themes.

children.title: Childlessness a cause of shame in Israel
The pain of childbirth a consequence of the fall
The need for ceremonial purification after childbirth

seealsos.comment: Under the old covenant, unsanctioned contact with blood was ceremonially defiling

children.title: The role of midwives in childbirth

primaryrefs.comment: Although childbirth is a focus of judgment, through it the human race continues, and the Messiah comes into the world.

A Christian mother fulfils her calling in childbearing; some take it to mean she will be kept safe in childbirth. Some, however, take this verse as a reference to Ge 3:15, and the coming of Jesus Christ, as above.

children.title: To describe troubles prior to God's final triumph
God controls the events of childbirth
Childbirth as an answer to prayer
Jesus Christ born of a virgin

seealsos.comment: ``impossible'' births demonstrate God's power and grace and show that salvation comes from the Lord.

children.title: children
children.comment: Scripture indicates that children are a gift from God and are to be loved, disciplined and cared for. The term ``children of God'' is used to describe Christian believers, who must grow up in the faith which they have accepted.

children.title: children, attitudes towards
children.comment: Christians must welcome children as Jesus Christ did. They are used by Christ as an example of how believers should receive the kingdom, and as an example of immaturity by Paul.

children.title: Children as a gift from God
Those who enter the kingdom must be like children
God's truth is revealed to the childlike
Children as people welcomed by Jesus Christ
Children as a picture of immature Christians
Warnings to those who cause children to stumble
Warnings to Israel, the disobedient child
children, needs of
children.comment: Children need love, affection, discipline and guidance from their parents. This is shown through teaching, training, discipline, the meeting of material needs and the provision of a personal example of faith.

children.title: Good examples set for children by parents
Bad examples set for children by parents

seealsos.comment: Jacob's special love for Joseph
David's love for Absalom
the father's love for the prodigal son

children.title: children, responsibilities to God
children.comment: The responsibilities of children to God as their heavenly Father include honouring and obeying him.

children.title: The responsibilities of children to their heavenly Father
To honour and obey him in reverent fear
Relationship to Jesus Christ transcends the child-parent relationship
children, responsibilities to parents
children.comment: Children owe their parents certain important responsibilities, including the duty to honour and obey them.

children.title: The duties of children towards their parents
They are to honour their parents
They are to obey their parents
Children as a blessing and source of joy to their parents
Children born to barren mothers bring special joy
Children as a source of grief and disappointment to their parents
The punishment of children for the sins of their fathers

secondaryrefs.comment: Jeremiah here stresses the importance of individual responsibility in the present crisis without denying the notion of corporate responsibility

children.title: children, examples of
children.comment: In Scripture specific children are marked out as belonging to the Lord. Mention of others is made in association with miracles or notable situations.

secondaryrefs.comment: the young girl who helped Naaman

children.title: Children in the miracles of Jesus Christ

secondaryrefs.comment: the boy who gave his lunch to help feed the crowd

children.title: children, attitudes towards
children.comment: Christians must welcome children as Jesus Christ did. They are used by Christ as an example of how believers should receive the kingdom, and as an example of immaturity by Paul.

children.title: Children as a gift from God

God's truth is revealed to the childlike

children.comment: Children need love, affection, discipline and guidance from their parents. This is shown through teaching, training, discipline, the meeting of material needs and the provision of a personal example of faith.

children.comment: The responsibilities of children to God as their heavenly Father include honouring and obeying him.

children.title: The responsibilities of children to their heavenly Father
To honour and obey him in reverent fear
Relationship to Jesus Christ transcends the child-parent relationship

children.comment: Children owe their parents certain important responsibilities, including the duty to honour and obey them.

children.title: The duties of children towards their parents
They are to honour their parents
They are to obey their parents
Children as a blessing and source of joy to their parents
Children born to barren mothers bring special joy
Children as a source of grief and disappointment to their parents
The punishment of children for the sins of their fathers

children.title: children, examples of
children.comment: In Scripture specific children are marked out as belonging to the Lord. Mention of others is made in association with miracles or notable situations.

secondaryrefs.comment: the young girl who helped Naaman

children.title: Children in the miracles of Jesus Christ

secondaryrefs.comment: the boy who gave his lunch to help feed the crowd

children.title: clan
children.comment: A social unit, larger than a family but smaller than a tribe.

cschildren.title: The responsibility of the clan for protection and revenge
The land allocated to the clans

children.title: concubines
children.comment: A woman, often a servant or slave, with whom a man had regular sexual relations, but to whom he was not married. A concubine did not have the rights of a wife and her children were not rightful heirs, though a wife might offer a servant to her husband as a concubine to have children on her behalf.

primaryrefs.comment: Having concubines alongside wives was accepted in a polygamous society.
Hagar was Abraham's ``wife'' only in a secondary sense.

seealsos.comment: Keturah was one of Abraham's concubines

children.title: Concubines did not have the rights of a wife

secondaryrefs.comment: They did have some legal protection.

primaryrefs.comment: Bilhah's sons would be regarded by Rachel as her own and would thus share the inheritance with Jacob's other sons.

children.title: The tension between concubines and wives

primaryrefs.comment: Though Abraham's concubine, Hagar's status was still that of servant.

children.title: Children born to concubines were not rightful heirs

cschildren.title: Concubines were a symbol of possession

children.title: By taking Jacob's concubine, Reuben laid premature claim to his father's estate
Taking the concubine(s) of a king was tantamount to laying claim to the kingdom

primaryrefs.comment: Abner is accused here of trying to usurp Ish-Bosheth's inheritance.

cschildren.title: Family responsibilities undertaken by cousins where there were no closer relatives

children.title: daughters
children.comment: The female offspring of parents. Daughters lived in their father's house, under his protection, until marriage. Usually they became his heirs only if he had no sons to inherit his estate. Normally they shared in the inheritance of their husbands.

children.title: Fathers were responsible for protecting their daughters
Examples of fathers who failed to protect their daughters
Fathers were responsible for arranging marriages for their daughters
Fathers received a bride-price from their daughters' husbands
Fathers gave a dowry to their daughters
Sometimes the marriage of a daughter was the basis of a political alliance
In cases of dispute, parents were expected to prove their daughter's virginity
If a man had no sons, the inheritance went to his daughters
Daughters who inherited their father's property were obliged to marry within his clan
Job allocated his daughters an inheritance
In dire circumstances fathers sometimes sold their daughters into slavery
A slave girl married to a son was to be accorded the rights of a daughter
Of an area, town or country or its population
Of the female inhabitants of an area, town or country
God's people are his sons and daughters
Family relationships must be subservient to one's relationship with God
divorce
children.comment: The legal dissolution of a marriage. Though not part of God's original intention for marriage, divorce is permitted under certain circumstances, especially marital unfaithfulness. In general, properly divorced parties are free to remarry.

children.title: divorce, in OT
children.comment: Usually initiated by the husband who issued his wife with a certificate of divorce and sent her from his home, divorce broke the marriage bond and allowed parties to remarry. It was not part of God's original purpose for marriage, and is permitted only because of human sinfulness. God is depicted as taking divorce proceedings against adulterous Israel.

primaryrefs.comment: The certificate of divorce was a legal document ending the marriage.

seealsos.comment: Divorce ends the restrictions on a priest's daughter which were the result of her marriage
Following divorce a husband is no longer responsible for his wife
Divorce properly entered into allows the parties to remarry

children.title: Divorce was not God's original intention

primaryrefs.comment: God's displeasure at those of his people who divorced their Jewish wives to marry foreigners, thus breaking faith with their partners and with God
The Law of Moses did not command divorce, but regulated an existing practice, particularly to protect the wife.

children.title: Returning exiles were required to divorce their foreign wives
Circumstances where divorce was not allowed

secondaryrefs.comment: where a husband makes false accusations about his wife's virginity
where the marriage is contracted following the rape of a virgin

children.title: The divorce between God and Israel
It was due to Israel's unfaithfulness
divorce, amongst believers
children.comment: Jesus Christ challenged the liberal approach to divorce taken by some rabbis of his day, and upheld the idea of marriage as a lifelong commitment. Remarriage after divorce is generally classed as adultery and, where possible, divorced parties should seek reconciliation. There are circumstances, however, where remarriage is permissible.

children.title: Divorce is permitted because of human sinfulness

primaryrefs.comment: This command, echoing Jesus Christ's words, applies where both parties are believers.

seealsos.comment: Marriage to another after divorce prevents reconciliation.

children.title: Remarriage after divorce is classed as adultery

primaryrefs.comment: This is a general rule, though there may be exceptions (see below).

secondaryrefs.comment: ``unmarried'' means literally ``freed from a wife'' and thus may be applied to those widowed or properly divorced. It is no sin for them to (re)marry.

children.title: Possible grounds for divorce and remarriage

seealsos.comment: God divorced Israel because of her adultery

children.title: divorce, in OT
children.comment: Usually initiated by the husband who issued his wife with a certificate of divorce and sent her from his home, divorce broke the marriage bond and allowed parties to remarry. It was not part of God's original purpose for marriage, and is permitted only because of human sinfulness. God is depicted as taking divorce proceedings against adulterous Israel.

primaryrefs.comment: The certificate of divorce was a legal document ending the marriage.

seealsos.comment: Divorce ends the restrictions on a priest's daughter which were the result of her marriage
Following divorce a husband is no longer responsible for his wife
Divorce properly entered into allows the parties to remarry

primaryrefs.comment: God's displeasure at those of his people who divorced their Jewish wives to marry foreigners, thus breaking faith with their partners and with God

Remarriage after divorce is generally classed as adultery and, where possible, divorced parties should seek reconciliation. There are circumstances, however, where remarriage is permissible.

children.title: Divorce is permitted because of human sinfulness

primaryrefs.comment: This command, echoing Jesus Christ's words, applies where both parties are believers.

seealsos.comment: Marriage to another after divorce prevents reconciliation.

seealsos.comment: God divorced Israel because of her adultery

children.title: dowry
children.comment: A present given by a woman's father on her marriage. At betrothal the bridegroom gave a compensatory gift, known as the bride-price, to the woman's family.

children.title: Usually it consisted of payment in kind

cschildren.title: The dowry given by the bride's father

children.title: family
children.comment: People who are linked by marriage or physical descent. The western idea of a ``nuclear'' family represents a narrow definition of the scope of the family. The ancient Near East had a broader and more extended understanding of family, which is often reflected in the Scriptural material.

children.title: family, nature of
children.comment: A unit ordained by God for the comfort and protection of its members. It is usually a group of relatives, but the people of God are also seen as a family.

children.title: The scope of the family in Scripture

seealsos.comment: The family of Obed-Edom is blessed by the presence of the ark
The wife of noble character provides for her family
The Philippian jailer and his family are baptised
the priesthood of Aaron and his family
Levirate marriage provides for the continuity of the family
Athaliah destroys the royal family of Judah

children.title: Marriage obligations and restrictions within the family
Marriage within the wider family circle was preferable in early times
The obligation to marry the widow of a dead brother
Laws of inheritance kept property within the family
family, significance of
children.comment: God created the family and is deeply concerned for its welfare. Scripture uses family metaphors to describe the relationship between God and his people.

children.title: God cares for the families of those who honour him
God judges families who disobey him
The extended family was the basic social unit
Families were to teach their children God's law
The relationship between God and his people described in family metaphors
They are brothers and sisters in God's family
Good family management as a qualification for church office
Christians are to support their families
The urgent demands of the kingdom of God should take priority over family responsibilities
family, nature of
children.comment: A unit ordained by God for the comfort and protection of its members. It is usually a group of relatives, but the people of God are also seen as a family.

They are brothers and sisters in God's family
Good family management as a qualification for church office

The urgent demands of the kingdom of God should take priority over family responsibilities
fathers
children.comment: The male parent of children. Scripture indicates the role and responsibilities of fathers, and shows how God can be thought of as a loving father, who directs and guides his children.

children.title: fathers, responsibilities of
children.comment: Fathers have a responsibility to love, instruct and discipline their children in the ways of the Lord. In return they are to be honoured and obeyed by their children.

children.title: To love and care for their children
To be honoured by their children
To be obeyed by their children
To be heeded by their children
Children's responsibility to honour their parents

primaryrefs.comment: ``Honour'' implies respect, obedience and care for the parents' needs.

children.title: The ministry of Jesus Christ may produce conflict within families
Following Jesus Christ involves a commitment to him even deeper than love of one's parents
fathers, examples of
children.comment: The ideal father, from a biblical perspective, is one who loves God, is obedient to him and reflects this in his daily living and in the care and upbringing of his children.

children.title: Fathers who followed divine principles within their families
The intercession of fathers for their children
fathers, responsibilities of
children.comment: Fathers have a responsibility to love, instruct and discipline their children in the ways of the Lord. In return they are to be honoured and obeyed by their children.

children.title: To love and care for their children
To be honoured by their children
To be obeyed by their children
To be heeded by their children

primaryrefs.comment: ``Honour'' implies respect, obedience and care for the parents' needs.

children.title: The ministry of Jesus Christ may produce conflict within families
Following Jesus Christ involves a commitment to him even deeper than love of one's parents
fathers, examples of
children.comment: The ideal father, from a biblical perspective, is one who loves God, is obedient to him and reflects this in his daily living and in the care and upbringing of his children.

children.title: Fathers who followed divine principles within their families
The intercession of fathers for their children
firstborn
children.comment: The firstborn male in a family; as in many cultures, in an Israelite family the eldest son had unique privileges, including the right of inheritance. The title ``firstborn'' was therefore a title of honour.

children.title: The place of honour in the family

primaryrefs.comment: In this and other lists, the firstborn is specially noted

children.title: The sin of despising these privileges

cschildren.title: The death of the firstborn a great tragedy

children.title: Repentance likened to grief over the death of a firstborn
The Levites consecrated in place of the firstborn
The offering of a firstborn insufficient to redeem from the consequences of sin

primaryrefs.comment: ``firstborn'' here means that Jesus Christ is above creation, rather than part of it. The title ``firstborn'' has strong Messianic associations

seealsos.comment: prophetic of Jesus Christ

children.title: friendlessness
children.comment: The bitter experience of the absence of friendship, leading to a sense of isolation and despair. It is often blamed on the faithlessness of others or even on God himself.

children.title: The lame man at the pool of Bethesda

cschildren.title: Cultivating true friends is the way to avoid friendlessness

children.title: friends
children.comment: Those to whom one is close. Scripture stresses that friendship is often but not always a positive thing: where good friends can be invaluable in the life of faith, bad friends can be obstacles to the faith of believers, or even lead them astray totally.

children.title: friends, good
children.comment: Those whose commitment from the heart is shown in practical, often sacrificial, care, love and service. They are a source of encouragement, sympathy, comfort and support in time of need. Such relationships are to be cultivated, especially among believers.

seealsos.comment: Titus
Epaphroditus
Tychicus
Luke
Timothy
Philemon

secondaryrefs.comment: the friends who brought the paralysed man to Jesus Christ

children.title: The benefits brought by good friends
Unity in the love and fear of the LORD

secondaryrefs.comment: A friend does not stir up trouble by spreading details of wrongs suffered, but rather seeks reconciliation

children.title: Jesus Christ is the friend of sinners
friends, bad
children.comment: Those who are close or who exercise influence, who prove to be unreliable or deceptive or who lead astray. Scripture provides numerous instructive examples of the negative effects of bad friends upon believers.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ is speaking about his betrayal by Judas.

primaryrefs.comment: Presumably these friends are not merely the ones who attempted to comfort him.

children.title: friends, good
children.comment: Those whose commitment from the heart is shown in practical, often sacrificial, care, love and service. They are a source of encouragement, sympathy, comfort and support in time of need. Such relationships are to be cultivated, especially among believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ is the friend of sinners
friends, bad
children.comment: Those who are close or who exercise influence, who prove to be unreliable or deceptive or who lead astray. Scripture provides numerous instructive examples of the negative effects of bad friends upon believers.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ is speaking about his betrayal by Judas.

primaryrefs.comment: Presumably these friends are not merely the ones who attempted to comfort him.

children.title: generation
children.comment: The population as a whole at any one time, or the interval of time separating parents and children.

cschildren.title: All the contemporaries of an individual
The passing of time expressed in terms of generations

seealsos.comment: the enduring consequences of rebellion
traditionally taken as referring to the Messiah

cschildren.title: The requirement to teach the next generation
Time references by specific numbers of generations
The generation that died in the wilderness
Jesus Christ's comments concerning his own wicked generation

children.title: girls
children.comment: Scripture provides insights into, and examples of, the way in which girls have a place in the purposes of God. Although the OT tends to portray girls mainly as potential wives or sexual partners, Jesus Christ's raising of Jairus' daughter can be seen as a symbol of the positive value placed on them.

cschildren.title: The portrayal of girls in the OT

primaryrefs.comment: This way of treating girls as mere sexual objects illustrates the moral corruption of the men of Gibeah. Though not condemned in this passage, such behaviour was totally contrary to OT law.

children.title: Chaste girls were to be protected but promiscuous girls were to be punished

cschildren.title: Girls undertaking various kinds of work
The place of girls in serving the purposes of God

children.title: Girls receive ministry from Jesus Christ and the apostles
Girls receive and use spiritual gifts
Examples of girls serving the purposes of God

secondaryrefs.comment: The example of this servant girl, instrumental in Naaman's healing, shows that girls have a value and a status before God not generally acknowledged in OT culture
Having become queen under the providence of God, Esther, chosen while a young virgin, is later able to use her influence to save the Jews from fierce persecution
Mary should be regarded as a girl, as she is a virgin betrothed and not a woman married.

children.title: The grandsons of the sons of Ulam

cschildren.title: Believing grandchildren have a responsibility to care for their grandparents
Believers have a responsibility to support their grandparents

children.title: He is guardian of his word
He is guardian of the world

cschildren.title: Christians are guardians of God's truth

children.title: guests
children.comment: People who receive hospitality, especially at others' homes. Guests are often invited to special celebrations such as weddings or birthdays. God invites all people as guests at his feast but many refuse.

children.title: Receiving Jesus Christ as a guest

primaryrefs.comment: Anointing with oil was a customary treatment for honoured guests.

seealsos.comment: It was usually the slave's duty to wash away dirt accumulated in travelling.

cschildren.title: God invites people to be his guests

children.title: headship
children.comment: The quality of being in a position of leadership or guidance. Headship has to do with God's relation to this created world, and to his ordering of relationships within it. Headship among human beings does not necessarily signify superior status, but rather a role of leadership and care. Scripture sees it as involving servanthood, and views Jesus Christ as the supreme model of this.

cschildren.title: God as head over all things

children.title: The Father's headship in the Son's earthly life and ministry

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as head of all creation

primaryrefs.comment: The description of Jesus Christ as the firstborn does not imply he is part of creation, but rather stresses his rights of inheritance over it.

children.title: Head of all earthly and spiritual powers
Head over all things at the end
Headship of rulers over their nations
Headship of chiefs over their tribes and families
Headship of the husband over his wife

seealsos.comment: Women, including wives, were told to cover their heads when praying or prophesying in public as an acknowledgment, apparently, that headship attaches to males

children.title: Headship of leaders over the people of God

seealsos.comment: The removal of headship and leadership is seen as a mark of God's judgment

children.title: Humility, love and respect are to be the framework for delegated headship
heir
children.comment: Property and power in biblical times normally descended from father to son. Jesus Christ is therefore called God's heir, and believers are said to inherit in him.

children.title: Lack of an heir regarded as a very serious matter

secondaryrefs.comment: The woman of Tekoa was interceding indirectly for Absalom, David's heir, who had been banished.

children.title: Daughters and other relatives could be heirs if there were no sons
Property could be inherited before death

secondaryrefs.comment: The prodigal son's request of inheritance before death could perhaps be regarded as an insult, but graciously the father complied out of love.

children.title: An heir must not give up his inheritance
The firstborn son was heir to a double share

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as the heir of God

children.title: Jesus Christ is heir as the Father's firstborn
Envy of Jesus Christ as heir
God himself as his people's inheritance
All believers are heirs by faith
Believers are heirs to the full rights of sons
Believers are heirs as the firstborn
Believers are heirs of eternal life
Believers are heirs of the earth
Believers are heirs of the kingdom
Believers are heirs of all things
Believers as heirs share Jesus Christ's throne
husband
children.comment: The male partner in a marriage relationship. The origin of this God-ordained institution is traced back in the Bible to the Garden of Eden. Scripture stresses that marriage is a God-ordained institution, within which the husband is pledged to love and care for his wife. Scripture contains many examples, both good and bad, of how husbands behaved. The ultimate examples of a good husband in Scripture are God as the husband of Israel and Jesus Christ as the bridegroom of the church.

children.title: Husband and wife are one flesh
The husband is head of the wife
To leave his parents and be united to his wife
To be faithful to his wife

cschildren.title: Behaviour which is commended in husbands
Behaviour which is condemned in husbands

children.title: inheritance
children.comment: A birthright or endowment, often in the form of goods or land, passed down from one generation to another. Scripture treats eternal life and other privileges of faith as an inheritance from God.

children.title: inheritance, material
children.comment: Family property was normally handed down in biblical times through sons, with a special place for the firstborn.  The land of Israel was regarded as the nation's inheritance.

children.title: It was normally handed down through sons
The absence of a son as a male heir was seen as a serious disadvantage

secondaryrefs.comment: The son's asking for his inheritance is perhaps to be seen as an insult.

children.title: It must not be fought over
Respect for the inheritance of others
It was confirmed to Moses and the patriarchs
Entry was denied because of sin
It was allotted to the tribes
It was a land for the godly
The LORD's inheritance in the land
The inheritance was lost through sin
The land was regained through grace

primaryrefs.comment: The Jews did return to the land; some look, however, for a further fulfilment of these promises in the future; others see them as fulfilled in Jesus Christ.

children.title: inheritance, spiritual
children.comment: Believers are privileged to receive a spiritual inheritance from their heavenly Father as a result of their adoption into the family of God through faith.

children.title: Believers have an inheritance in Christ
Believers are heirs under the covenant
The nature of the spiritual inheritance of believers
They have the full rights of sons
They have the rights of the firstborn
Their inheritance is the word of God
The permanence of believers' spiritual inheritance
It has been prepared from the creation
It is sealed with God's promise
It is conditional upon continuing obedience and faith
It is denied to the ungodly

children.comment: Family property was normally handed down in biblical times through sons, with a special place for the firstborn.  The land of Israel was regarded as the nation's inheritance.

children.comment: Believers are privileged to receive a spiritual inheritance from their heavenly Father as a result of their adoption into the family of God through faith.

male and female
children.comment: God created humanity as male and female. Although gender differences are evident in behaviour and role, Scripture teaches the equality and complementarity of the sexes.

cschildren.title: The creation of male and female
The fall disrupted relationships between male and female
The equality of male and female

children.title: Equality under many old covenant regulations

cschildren.title: Variations in the treatment of male and female

children.title: In legislation protecting women under the old covenant
In roles within the NT church community

seealsos.comment: The idea of ``headship'' is complex, but is generally regarded as including the ideas of responsibility and authority within a relationship

children.title: In behaviour within the NT church community

cschildren.title: Male and female roles within marriage
Male and female imagery used of God

children.title: marriage
children.comment: The union of a man and a woman in a permanent relationship. Though a lifelong monogamous commitment is presented as the ideal, polygamous marriages were occasionally known in OT times and carried the same legal and moral rights and responsibilities. God's relationship with his people is described in terms of the marriage bond.

children.title: marriage, purpose of
children.comment: Marriage is part of God's intention for humanity from creation and forms the basis for the family which is the primary unit of society. Where marriage flourishes it blesses both the couple and the wider community.

children.title: Marriage is part of God's plan for the human race

seealsos.comment: Man and woman are not independent of each other.

children.title: It is to be a committed, exclusive relationship
It is the intended context for raising children
It will not exist in the life to come

seealsos.comment: A woman was expected to be a virgin when she married.
Marital unfaithfulness is condemned

children.title: Falling in love prior to marriage
Husbands are to love their wives
Wives are to submit to their husbands
Celibacy as a calling from God

seealsos.comment: Whilst Paul commends the unmarried state, for those not so called it is no sin to marry

children.title: marriage, customs concerning
children.comment: Marriage between two individuals united their families and involved the whole community. Parents, particularly fathers, took an active part in selecting partners for their children. There was often a long period of betrothal; wedding celebrations were usually elaborate and might last a week or more.

children.title: The choice of a marriage partner
Parents usually chose a suitable partner

seealsos.comment: Occasionally mothers made the wedding arrangements.

primaryrefs.comment: Rebekah is consulted about her proposed marriage to Isaac.

children.title: Daughters were given as a reward
Gifts from the bride's father
children.precomment: Servants given to the bride as a dowry:

children.title: Betrothal followed payment of the bride-price

seealsos.comment: Jacob worked for Laban during his period of betrothal to Rachel.

children.title: A betrothed couple were regarded as husband and wife

secondaryrefs.comment: Unfaithfulness during the period of betrothal is treated as adultery
Divorce is required to break a betrothal.

children.title: Sexual relationships took place only after the wedding

secondaryrefs.comment: Engaged soldiers were to marry before going into battle
Recently married soldiers were exempted from military service for a year.

children.title: The bride wore an elaborate dress and jewellery

primaryrefs.comment: An allegorical description of God dressing Jerusalem as a bride.

children.title: Attendants on the bride and groom

secondaryrefs.comment: Invited guests were called when the feast was ready.
Guests were expected to dress appropriately.

children.title: marriage, restrictions concerning
children.comment: The OT law forbade intermarriage with people who worshipped idols because it threatened the covenant relationship with God and his people. Marriage with close relations was also forbidden. Remarriage is permissible following the death of a spouse and, in certain circumstances, following divorce.

children.title: Intermarriage with foreigners led to idolatry

primaryrefs.comment: Royal marriages to foreigners brought disastrous consequences.

children.title: Parents sought to avoid their children marrying foreigners

seealsos.comment: Abraham seeks a bride for Isaac from among his own people.
Isaac forbids Jacob to marry a Canaanite woman
Samson's parents encourage him to marry an Israelite.

children.title: Marriage to foreigners may be permissible

secondaryrefs.comment: Boaz' marriage to Ruth the Moabitess was acceptable because Ruth embraced the Israelite faith. Restrictions were on the grounds of religion not of race.

children.title: Foreign wives were put aside after the exile
Christians should not leave an unbelieving spouse
Restrictions on marriage to close relatives
Sexual relations with close relatives is forbidden
Examples of marriage to close relatives

secondaryrefs.comment: Abraham was married to his half-sister
Tamar suggests marriage with her half-brother, Amnon.

children.title: The levirate law was instituted to preserve the dead father's name

primaryrefs.comment: Levirate marriage refers to the legal obligation of a brother-in-law to produce heirs for his dead brother by marrying his widow. When there was no brother-in-law responsibility fell to a near relative, also described as a ``kinsman-redeemer''.

children.title: Unwillingness to fulfil the levirate law
Remarriage after divorce may be adultery
Remarriage after divorce permissible in certain circumstances
marriage, between God and his people
children.comment: Marriage is used to describe the relationship between God and Israel in the OT and between Jesus Christ and the church in the NT. Contemplating marriage deepens understanding of God's love for his people; examining God's covenant love for his people similarly enriches an understanding of marriage.

primaryrefs.comment: The covenant at Sinai was seen as a form of marriage.

children.title: The breakdown of God's marriage to Israel
Israel's alienation from God is likened to a divorce

primaryrefs.comment: Israel's unfaithfulness led to a form of divorce between God and his people. This was sometimes identified with the exile.

children.title: The renewal of God's marriage to Israel
God calls his bride to return
Jesus Christ's marriage relationship with the church
Jesus Christ's love as a model for marriage
Jesus Christ is described as a bridegroom

primaryrefs.comment: John the Baptist describes Jesus Christ as the bridegroom and himself as the best man.

God calls his bride to return

Jesus Christ is described as a bridegroom

primaryrefs.comment: John the Baptist describes Jesus Christ as the bridegroom and himself as the best man.

children.title: men
children.comment: God created both men and women in his image and likeness. Scripture portrays men in both their strengths and weaknesses, their successes and failures. While noting that they are incomplete without women, and share equally in the privileges and tasks entrusted to them by God, men have nevertheless been given specific responsibilities by God.

children.title: Men are equal with women in creation
Absence of men in society seen as a curse
Men are equal with women in redemption
As leaders in marriage and family life
As leaders in Israelite society and worship
As leaders in the early church

seealsos.comment: The role of teaching and exercising authority is here restricted to men. Interpretations vary as to whether Paul is reflecting cultural circumstance or establishing theological principle

primaryrefs.comment: While courage can be exercised by all, it is identified here as a specifically male characteristic.

children.title: To be good fathers to their children

seealsos.comment: Jacob's favouritism was the cause of resentment developing in the family
Eli is rebuked for having failed to father his sons properly

primaryrefs.comment: That Paul is particularly thinking of men here seems apparent from the NIV footnote at verse 4.

cschildren.title: Examples of godly men who had moments of failure

secondaryrefs.comment: David committed adultery with Bathsheba and plotted Uriah's death
Elijah became fearful and wanted to die
Jonah ran from God's call on his life
Paul and Barnabas fell into sharp disagreement.
The ungodliness of the men of Sodom lay in sexual immorality
Onan's ungodliness lay in failing to fulfil his obligations to his brother's wife
Korah's ungodliness lay in rebellion against God's leaders
Eli's sons' ungodliness lay in their abuse of the sacrifices
Ahab's ungodliness lay in intermarriage and idolatry
Manasseh's ungodliness lay in idolatry, divination and human sacrifice
Herod's ungodliness lay in the wholesale slaughter of infants
Herod the tetrarch's ungodliness lay in immorality and murder
Simon's ungodliness lay in the practice of magic
The ungodliness of men in the church lay in their rejection of apostolic doctrine and lifestyle.
Isaac's fear of the Philistines led him to lie
The spies' fear led them to give a bad report
Saul's fear of the Philistines led him to enquire of a medium when the LORD did not answer him
Ish-Bosheth's fear of his brother led him to stay silent concerning sin
Pilate's fear of the crowd led him to condemn Jesus Christ, even though he knew he was innocent
Felix' fear arose from the message of the gospel.
Men who are disobedient to God will be weak
Eli's weakness lay in failing to restrain his sons
Ahab's weakness lay in his allowing his wife to rule his life and his kingdom.

cschildren.title: A woman was considered ceremonially unclean during menstruation

children.title: middle age
children.comment: The period between youth and old age. Middle age is marked by physical strength and experience and should bring maturity and stability. Many of God's servants began ministry in middle age, often after having been prepared in their youth. Middle age may also bring complacency and the temptation to leave the devotion and commitments of youth.

primaryrefs.comment: Strength is greatest between 20 and 60.

seealsos.comment: Men served in the army from age 20
Caleb, in his prime at 40, is still strong at 85.

children.title: The need to be prepared for these responsibilities

seealsos.comment: Solomon passes on wisdom learned from his father.

children.title: The need to train for service

primaryrefs.comment: The period from 25 to 30 (see Nu 4:3) may have been a period of apprenticeship.

seealsos.comment: In later years the apprenticeship may have started at 20

children.title: The start of service in middle age

seealsos.comment: Moses showed concern for his fellow Israelites at age 40
Caleb was 40 when he explored Canaan
Samuel became judge over Israel in his thirties
John the Baptist began his public ministry at about 30
Jesus Christ had not achieved the status of wisdom and authority associated with old age in Israel
The mention of families in the instructions to elders and deacons suggests that these leaders were of middle age.

children.title: Rulers coming to office in middle age
Turning from the commitment of youth
monogamy
children.comment: The practice of having and remaining faithful to only one marriage partner at one time. It is set out as God's ideal for human relationships; an ideal demonstrated in the use of the marriage bond to portray the relationship between God and his people.

cschildren.title: Monogamy as God's original intention for marriage
Monogamy is shown in God's relationship with his people

children.title: The commitment to a lifelong, loving companionship

primaryrefs.comment: The satisfaction that may be found in marriage makes marital unfaithfulness and polygamy unnecessary.
Favouritism within polygamous relationships undermines the close companionship which should characterise marriage.

cschildren.title: Monogamy is implicit in teaching about divorce

primaryrefs.comment: This is an implicit, but clear prohibition of polygamy
Monogamy is obligatory in leaders.

children.title: mothers
children.comment: The female parent of children. The role and influence of mothers are frequently stressed in Scripture, and their care for children is used as a picture of God's care for his people.

children.title: mothers, responsibilities of
children.comment: The fundamental importance of motherhood is recognised throughout Scripture.

children.title: God plans happiness for women in motherhood
The need for a mother's cleansing after childbirth
A mother's relationship with her children
A mother loves and cares for her children

primaryrefs.comment: Paul's statement assumes that a mother's normal attitude towards her child is one of love and care.

children.title: The joy or sorrow of parents at their children's conduct
The negative influence of some mothers upon their children
Children's reponsibility to honour their parents

primaryrefs.comment: ``Honour'' implies respect, obedience and care for the parents' needs.

children.title: This honour is due especially to mothers in old age
Sexual relations with one's mother or mother-in-law are forbidden
Upon marriage the mother-child relationship becomes secondary
The ministry of Jesus Christ may produce conflict within families
Following Jesus Christ involves a commitment to him even deeper than love of one's parents
Jesus Christ regards those who do God's will as his own family
mothers, examples of
children.comment: Examples are given in Scripture of notable mothers, mothers-in-law and grandmothers.

children.title: Eve, the mother of all the living
Rebekah, mother of Esau and Jacob
Rachel, mother of Joseph and Benjamin
Jezebel, who taught her sons to worship Baal rather than the LORD
Elizabeth, mother of John the Baptist
Rufus' mother, a mother to Paul
Lois and Eunice, a godly grandmother and a mother
mothers, as a symbol
children.comment: Motherhood is used in Scripture to illustrate the relationship between God and his people, to describe certain aspects of Israel and also to explain the difference between the two covenants.

children.title: God's tender care for his children is like a mother's
God's care like that of a mother bird
Becoming a Christian is like birth
The believer trusts God as a weaned child trusts his or her mother
Mothers as symbols of the old and new covenants

nobles
children.comment: People of high rank who therefore had great power and importance.

cschildren.title: Nobles had great power and importance
Nobles' abuse of their rank and power
God's judgment of nobles who abused their power

children.title: offspring
children.comment: Literally, physical descendants, and figuratively, the recipients of a spiritual inheritance.

children.title: Offspring as a blessing to parents
Offspring as a blessing to others
Absence of offspring seen as a sadness or curse
Steps to be taken to provide offspring under the law
Offspring as a result of God's special intervention
God's claim on the firstborn offspring
Offspring can inherit parents' blessing or punishment
The fate of the offspring of the wicked
Human beings, the offspring of God through creation
Believers, spiritual offspring through new birth
old age
children.comment: Living for a relatively long time was regarded as a blessing from God and the aged in society are to be respected. Advancing years can bring greater wisdom and in both the OT and NT elders are given authority and leadership. Old age brings physical weakness and Scripture recognises this but states God's ability to strengthen and sustain the aged.

children.title: old age, attainment of
children.comment: Attaining old age is regarded as a blessing from God, often as a reward for obedience. The physical weakness brought by old age is recognised; so too is God's ability to strengthen and sustain the aged. Old age is often accompanied by a growth in wisdom and discernment.

secondaryrefs.comment: Methuselah died in the year of the flood

seealsos.comment: Following the flood, the span of life gradually reduces
Abraham's death at 175 is considered ``a good old age''.

children.title: Attaining old age is a blessing from God
Long life as a reward for obedience
Reaching old age is a mark of God's favour

seealsos.comment: Isaac
Gideon
David, like Abraham and Gideon is described as dying at ``a good old age''
Jehoiada
Job

children.title: People reaching old age indicates God's blessing on society
Seeing grandchildren is a sign of blessing
Failure to reach old age is a result of God's judgment

seealsos.comment: an allegory portraying physical decline

children.title: The progressive inability to have children

seealsos.comment: Children born in old age were rare and therefore special

children.title: Wisdom and self-control should accompany old age
old age, attitudes to
children.comment: Old age is generally held in honour and the aged in society are to be respected. Because of the wisdom associated with their advancing years elders had an important role of authority and guidance in Israelite society and the NT speaks of the leadership of elders within the church.

children.title: Old age is to be held in honour
Old age is associated with wisdom
Deferring to the wisdom of the aged

seealsos.comment: Rehoboam rejected the advice of elders and rebellion ensued
Paul refers to his age to add authority to his words.

children.title: Old age does not necessarily bring superior wisdom
Showing disrespect for the elderly is a sign of evil days
The role and status of elders
Elders in Israel
children.precomment: Israel's elders were probably the heads of families, qualified to lead by virtue of age and experience:

secondaryrefs.comment: The number of elders is reduced to 70 who are anointed by the Spirit for leadership alongside Moses.
Israel's elders accept David as king
Jewish elders were among those who tried Jesus Christ. By NT times they had become involved with religious as well as civil affairs and their title related more to their role than to age.

primaryrefs.comment: This description of God as the ``Ancient of Days'' implies that he possesses the respectability, authority and wisdom to judge that accompanies age. It also points to his eternity.

children.precomment: Israel's elders were probably the heads of families, qualified to lead by virtue of age and experience:

secondaryrefs.comment: The number of elders is reduced to 70 who are anointed by the Spirit for leadership alongside Moses.
Israel's elders accept David as king
Jewish elders were among those who tried Jesus Christ. By NT times they had become involved with religious as well as civil affairs and their title related more to their role than to age.

primaryrefs.comment: This description of God as the ``Ancient of Days'' implies that he possesses the respectability, authority and wisdom to judge that accompanies age. It also points to his eternity.

children.title: one flesh
children.comment: A sign and expression of the inseparable union between husband and wife. This is not only physical but emotional, mental and spiritual. It is also used to describe the union between Jesus Christ and the church.

cschildren.title: One flesh describes the inseparable union between husband and wife
One flesh refers to sexual union which Scripture describes in various ways

children.title: To have union or unite with

cschildren.title: One flesh expresses an intimacy encouraged by God

children.title: Intimate relations between members of the same sex are unnatural and wrong

cschildren.title: One flesh describes the union between Jesus Christ and the church

children.title: orphans
children.comment: Children whose parents are dead; a vulnerable group of people to whom God shows special kindness. He expects his people to do the same. Those who exploit them incur God's judgment.

cschildren.title: God expects his people to care for orphans

children.title: They are not to be oppressed

cschildren.title: Exploitation of orphans is a mark of wickedness
God punishes those who oppress orphans
Orphans are included among God's people
Jesus Christ includes those who are spiritually fatherless

children.title: parents
children.comment: Scripture stipulates that children should show respect and concern for their parents.

cschildren.title: Love between parents and children can be suppressed
Love for God must surpass love for parents
The belief that children were punished for their parents' sins
Parents and the marriage of their children

children.title: A man leaves his parents to marry his wife
Parents were responsible for vindicating their daughter's reputation
Sometimes parents jointly arranged their children's marriages
polygamy
children.comment: The practice of having more than one wife at one time. Although not explicitly forbidden in Scripture as a general practice, it is presented as problematic and monogamy is the clearly preferred option.

cschildren.title: Monogamy is God's intention for marriage
Reasons for the practice of polygamy

primaryrefs.comment: A large family, and especially numerous progeny, was regarded as a sign of divine blessing.
It was common for kings to cement foreign alliances by marriage. Israel's king is warned against the practice

seealsos.comment: Sarah and Hagar
Hannah and Peninnah
the conflict over the succession to David's throne
Ahab
Jehoiachin
Ashhur
Belshazzar

secondaryrefs.comment: Polygamy is expressly forbidden for church leaders.

cschildren.title: Pregnancy regarded as a blessing from God
Pregnancy in troubled times sometimes a misfortune

children.title: Because of atrocities committed in war
Because of additional hardship in harsh circumstances
relationships
children.comment: God created people to be in relationship with himself and with one another in friendship, marriage, family, society and the church.

cschildren.title: Human beings are created to be in relationship

primaryrefs.comment: This is often known as the covenant formula.

children.title: Believers are to be in relationship with one another in the church
Believers are to maintain good relationships
Believers are to restore broken relationships
sexuality
children.comment: Men and women are intended to complement one another and to take pleasure in one another. God has provided for the full and glad expression of this in marriage.

children.title: God intended men and women to complement one another

primaryrefs.comment: This command was made before the fall, and no guilt attaches to it.
``one flesh'' implies both bodily union and an inseparable intimate relationship.

``Song of Songs'' celebrates the beauty of sex in a loving context. It contains much delicate and intimate imagery that applies directly to human lovers and can also be applied to Jesus Christ and the church.
Lust may also lead to other sexual sins.

children.title: singleness
children.comment: Not being married; the state prior to betrothal or following separation or the death of a spouse. In Scripture, an unmarried woman generally lives with, and is the responsibility of, her family. Whilst the unmarried are freer of worldly concerns and may devote themselves more fully to God, those already married should not separate, and those without the gift of celibacy should not remain single.

children.title: An unmarried woman is responsible to her father
An unmarried woman is dependent on her brothers
Widowed or divorced women could return to their parents' home

cschildren.title: The unwelcome prospect of remaining unmarried

children.title: Celibacy is a calling from God
Believers should remain as they are when called
Sexual abstinence within marriage is strictly limited
The unmarried may devote themselves to God
Marriage belongs to a passing order
sisters
children.comment: The daughter of one's parents, or of either mother or father. The relationship with a sister is a close one, especially with an unmarried sister.

cschildren.title: The relationship with a sister was a close one
A brother had some measure of responsibility for his sister

children.title: Marrying a sister was permissible in pre-Mosaic times
Sexual relationships with a sister were later forbidden in Mosaic law

secondaryrefs.comment: Dinah's rape was avenged by her brothers
Tamar was raped by her half-brother

cschildren.title: Sometimes the wives of the patriarchs posed as their sisters
Examples of the behaviour of sisters

children.title: Marriage to a sister-in-law was allowed in specific circumstances
Sexual relationships with sisters-in-law were forbidden under normal circumstances

cschildren.title: Sister used as a term of affection

children.title: Describing the relationship of believers to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ requires his followers to put him before family ties
sons
children.comment: The male offspring of parents. While sharing in the general privileges and responsibilities of children, sons had special claims to inheritance from their parents. To refer to Christians as ``sons of God'' is to identify both their relationship to God and also their rights as heirs of God. A significant number of titles for Jesus Christ make use of the term ``Son'', stressing the close relationship between the Father and Son.

children.title: Being disciplined
children.precomment: Discipline is here seen as a loving means of enabling a child to grow to maturity:

secondaryrefs.comment: The voluntary obedience of the child Jesus towards Mary and Joseph is widely regarded as setting an example for believers.

cschildren.title: Family relationships must be subservient to one's relationship with God
Titles of Jesus Christ as Son

children.title: Son of Joseph
children.precomment: Jesus Christ is described in this way by those who have yet to understand the circumstances of his conception and birth:

children.title: twins
children.comment: Two children born of the same parents at the same time. Figuratively used to describe a matching pair.

primaryrefs.comment: Although Jacob and Esau were twins, their very different characters indicate that God deals with and relates to people individually.

seealsos.comment: Didymus means ``twin''. It is not known who his twin was
the mythical twin sons of Zeus regarded as special protectors of sailors

cschildren.title: Twins used to illustrate God's election
Twins used figuratively for matching pairs

children.title: virgin
children.comment: Generally a young person, especially a female, who has not had sexual intercourse. Virginity is an important quality in a bride, and its surrender or violation prior to marriage is sternly condemned. In the miracle of the incarnation, Mary was still a virgin when Jesus Christ was conceived. Virginity is also used metaphorically to denote purity and innocence.

cschildren.title: Virginity is important in a bride

seealsos.comment: The word translated ``maiden'' might also refer to a virgin

children.title: The church presented as a virgin bride

cschildren.title: The loss of virginity before marriage

children.title: Of a virgin not pledged in marriage
Of a virgin pledged in marriage

seealsos.comment: Betrothal was as serious a commitment as marriage itself; consorting with another person during this period was tantamount to adultery

children.title: Some fathers surrendered their daughters' virginity
A virgin looked after King David

cschildren.title: Virginity as a sign of purity and innocence

children.title: Virgins were spared after military victories

cschildren.title: Virginity as a metaphor for (apparent) inviolability

children.title: A virgin is freer to serve God

primaryrefs.comment: The unmarried have fewer responsibilities and worldly cares and so may offer undivided devotion to God.

children.title: Remaining unmarried is a preferred option
Marriage is the proper outlet for sexual passion

secondaryrefs.comment: Though Paul urges abstinence, sexual passion is not wrong; however, sexual relationships must be confined to marriage

cschildren.title: Mary's virginity at Jesus Christ's conception

children.title: vows
children.comment: Promises made to God, usually in the context of worship or religious practice. There was no requirement on any Israelite to make vows, but once made, they were binding and had to be kept.

primaryrefs.comment: In certain cases vows made by daughters or wives could be nullified by fathers or husbands respectively.

cschildren.title: Vows made to God in the context of worship

children.title: To dedicate people, animals or property to God

secondaryrefs.comment: Samson was set apart as a Nazirite from birth
Samuel may have been a Nazirite.

cschildren.title: Examples of vows made to God

children.title: wedding
children.comment: The public acknowledgment and celebration of a couple's marriage. The wedding followed betrothal and was a preliminary to sexual union. The occasion was marked by feasting, singing and rejoicing. The bride wore a wedding dress, jewellery and ornaments and both she and the groom were waited on by attendants.

seealsos.comment: A feast celebrates Jacob's wedding
a wedding banquet given by a king for his son
Jesus Christ changes water into wine at a wedding feast
the marriage supper of the Lamb
Wedding guests were expected to wear appropriate clothes

children.title: Covering the bride
children.precomment: Sometimes the groom would cover the bride with his cloak as a symbol of protection:

children.title: widows
children.comment: God's tender concern for bereaved wives is declared throughout the whole of Scripture. He defends their rights and expects his people to do the same.

cschildren.title: God is the protector of widows
Widows are to be treated justly
Widows are not to be exploited
The law requires God's people to provide for widows

seealsos.comment: The prophet encourages God's people to return to the law.

cschildren.title: The Christian community are to care for widows
Examples of widows and their treatment
Women widowed because of God's judgment
Laws governing the remarriage of widows

primaryrefs.comment: The OT emphasises continuity of the family line.

seealsos.comment: Boaz refers to the law which gave the nearest male relative the duty of marrying the widow

cschildren.title: Widowhood as the personification of a city

primaryrefs.comment: A lament for desolate Jerusalem.

seealsos.comment: a prophecy of the restoration of Jerusalem
the boasts of Babylon

children.title: wife
children.comment: The female partner in a marriage relationship. The origin of this God-ordained institution is traced back in the Bible to the Garden of Eden. Scripture stresses that marriage is a God-ordained institution, within which the husband should love and care for his wife, just as the wife should obey, honour and care for her husband. A good wife is portrayed as a great blessing, but a bad wife influences her husband for evil. In the OT, Israel is sometimes portrayed as God's wife; in the NT, the church is described as Christ's bride.

children.title: Husband and wife are one flesh
The wife as helper and companion
The husband is head of the wife
The wife is the weaker partner

cschildren.title: The Israelites were forbidden to take foreign wives

children.title: To submit to and respect her husband
To care for her husband and household
To be faithful to her husband

cschildren.title: Wives influencing their husbands for evil
Israel as the wife of God

primaryrefs.comment: Israel's relationship with God was at times comparable to that of an unfaithful wife

cschildren.title: The church as the bride of Christ

children.title: women
children.comment: God created both women and men in his image and likeness. Scripture shows women in a variety of roles, playing an important part in God's salvation plan. In Christ, there is no fundamental distinction between believers on account of gender, race or social status. Women played a significant part in the life of Jesus Christ and in the early church. The NT both records their role and faces the questions thereby raised.

cschildren.title: Examples of women who are condemned or judged
Women in office in the OT
Women as wives and mothers in the OT
Women in the life of Jesus Christ

children.title: In the ministry of Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ respected women and talked to them as individuals with spiritual understanding. This was a considerable deviation from the cultural conventions of the time.

cschildren.title: Women's ministry in the early church

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote at verse 1.
Interpreters disagree over whether Junias was a man or a woman, and also over whether Paul meant these two were notable in the ranks of the apostles or were well-known to the apostles.

children.title: The equality of the sexes and rejection of female subordination

Women who are strong role models
youth
children.comment: Scripture characterises youth as a time of vigour and strength. It speaks, too, of the pressures and expectations of youth, warns about the temptations facing young people, and instructs the young about what is expected of them.

primaryrefs.comment: Even youthful strength and vigour may fail.

children.title: To remain faithful to one's partner

secondaryrefs.comment: Joash became king at the age of seven
Josiah became king at the age of eight
Jesus Christ at the age of twelve

children.title: Dying young as a sign of judgment

seealsos.comment: The death of children and young people symbolises loss of hope for the future

children.title: Troubles faced from the time of one's youth
